Top Twenty Tool Tryst On the Road with PaaS

Inspired by Rands In Repose Foamy Rules for Rabid Tools.

Take a break, insert fresh sheet of creamy bond, and list the best tools you’ve encountered since you started messing with computers. By “best tools” I mean any “thing” (language, IDE, library, framework, process, service, design pattern, coding technique, test suite, methodology, the list goes on) that first, significantly improves (has improved) life for you as a developer and second, is a true pleasure to behold.

Everyone’s list is different. Mine is based on nothing more than the shear joy I feel when I use these tools. These are listed in no particular order, except that for some reason emacs always seems to top the list.

best tools EVER




emacs

Opa

I think Opa represents the future of web development. I just wrote about this in fact. http://blog.bcferrycoder.com/2012/11/17/i-have-seen-the-future/

Intellij Idea

I was staunchly opposed to using any sort of IDE given the first entry in this list. Then a famous person convinced me to “just try NetBeans” so i did, and I never turned back. Later I tried IDEA and THEN I never turned back. IDEA makes Java fun again.

MTS Macros

Ruby on Rails

In 2005 I built an internal Sun app based on Java Server Faces, then shortly thereafter migrated the same app to Ruby on Rails. I kept hearing “90% code reduction” blah blah, didn’t believe it, just hype.

Then I measured the LoC before/after and… it achieved almost 90%.

And Ruby alone seems to reduce annoying and unnecessary syntax by about the same amount. I’m a fan.
